senses.sense_definition: To start a line of text further from the margin than the main part of the text.

examples.text: You should <w>indent</w> the first line of every paragraph to make the text easier to read.
The software will automatically <w>indent</w> the code when you press the tab key.

senses.sense_definition: To make a depression or mark into a surface by pressing or striking.

examples.text: The heavy hail began to <w>indent</w> the metal roof of the car.
He managed to <w>indent</w> the soft wood with a hammer.

senses.sense_definition: To cut notches, points, or irregularities into an edge or border.

examples.text: Many small bays and inlets <w>indent</w> the coastline of the island.
The craftsman used a tool to <w>indent</w> the edge of the coin.

senses.sense_definition: To officially request or order supplies, especially in a military or administrative context.

examples.text: The officer had to <w>indent</w> for fresh ammunition and rations.
We must <w>indent</w> upon the central store for new equipment.

senses.sense_definition: To bind someone by a formal contract to work for a specific period.

examples.text: In the past, parents would often <w>indent</w> their children to a master craftsman.
He agreed to <w>indent</w> himself as a servant for four years in exchange for passage.

senses.sense_definition: A cut, notch, or small hollow space in a surface or edge.

examples.text: There was a small <w>indent</w> on the frame where the lock fits.
Make a slight <w>indent</w> in the clay with your thumb before baking it.

senses.sense_definition: An official requisition or order for supplies.

examples.text: The captain signed an <w>indent</w> for the necessary medical supplies.
Please submit your <w>indent</w> to the procurement department by Friday.
